content.text:
<image 1>A student performs the photoelectric effect experiment and obtains the data depicted in the accompanying graph of E_{km} (maximum kinetic energy) of photoelectrons v. the frequency of the photons. What is the approximate work function of this material?

A. 1.5 eV
B. 2.0 eV
C. 2.7 eV
D. 3.5 eV

To determine the work function of the material from the given graph, we need to look at the threshold frequency (the frequency at which the kinetic energy \( E_{km} \) becomes zero). The work function \( \phi \) is related to the threshold frequency \( f_0 \) by the equation:

\[ \phi = h f_0 \]

where \( h \) is Planck's constant.

From the graph, we can see that the kinetic energy \( E_{km} \) becomes zero at a frequency of approximately \( 4 \times 10^{14} \) Hz. This is the threshold frequency \( f_0 \).

Now, we can calculate the work function using the threshold frequency:

\[ \phi = h f_0 \]

Using the value of Planck's constant \( h = 6.626 \times 10^{-34} \) Js and the threshold frequency \( f_0 = 4 \times 10^{14} \) Hz:

\[ \phi = (6.626 \times 10^{-34} \text{ Js}) \times (4 \times 10^{14} \text{ Hz}) \]
\[ \phi = 2.6504 \times 10^{-19} \text{ J} \]

To convert joules to electron volts (eV), we use the conversion factor \( 1 \text{ eV} = 1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ J} \):

\[ \phi = \frac{2.6504 \times 10^{-19} \text{ J}}{1.602 \times 10^{-19} \text{ J/eV}} \]
\[ \phi \approx 1.654 \text{ eV} \]

The closest option to 1.654 eV is:

A. 1.5 eV

So, the approximate work function of the material is 1.5 eV.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
